repnme.cdata!:
Republic of Congo - Emergency
            Demobilization and Reintegration Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The ratings for the Emergency
            Demobilization and Reintegration Project for the Republic of
            Congo are as follows: Project outcome is unsatisfactory;
            sustainability is likely; institutional development impact
            is modest; Bank performance is unsatisfactory; and Borrower
            performance is unsatisfactory. The project's lack of
            success reflects the Bank's overall lack of
            preparedness to engage in post conflict settings. On the
            positive side, a small operation of this nature,
            specifically designed to deal with threats to stability, can
            make a difference in moving a post-conflict country away
            from the conflict-trap. In this regard, the
            Government's strong commitment to the peace process and
            to the project was an important factor. Following are more
            detailed considerations: The Bank 1) should more thoroughly
            consider the consequences of packaging together more
            traditional approaches to macro-economic stability,
            financial management and social services with post-conflict
            measures that more directly help stability and buy political
            time; 2) review its internal policies and procedures to
            determine their suitability for post-conflict interventions,
            and define their comparative advantage as a partner in such
            interventions; 3) coordinate with national and international
            partners to ensure synergy; 4) achieve the appropriate skill
            mix in the team, including the necessary political and
            technical expertise in post-conflict peace building and
            recovery; 5) closely link demobilization and reintegration
            of ex-combatants to an organized collection of weapons,
            particularly relevant in a situation where no UN or regional
            peacekeeping force is deployed; 6) where similar programs
            have preceded a project and targeted the same beneficiary
            group, establish coordination as well as operational links
            between databases to avoid double-dipping and inconsistency
            of approaches, that may create tension between the different
            groups of beneficiaries; 7) focus on social issues, such as
            reintegrating ex-combatants into communities as well as on
            the gender aspects of demobilization and use indicators that
            would trace the impact of the program on women and young
            males; 8) streamlining the processing of applications by
            ex-combatants by decentralizing to avoid bureaucratic delays
            in delivering benefits (which could lead to loss of
            confidence and abandoned micro-projects); 9) requiring
            several layers of screening to verify ex-combatants'
            status including using non-falsifiable ID cards to protect
            against possible abuse; and 10) closing monitoring
            withdrawal applications by and disbursements to the borrower
            to ensure a steady flow of funding to a potentially volatile
            beneficiary population. Post-conflict interventions, while
            short-term in nature, require sustained follow-up to deal
            with ex-combatants who remain armed while unemployed and
            thus potentially mobilized for political or military
            purposes, along with social tensions between the winners and
            losers of the war remaining a source of concern and many
            governance issues, including corruption and natural
            resources management, Therefore, continued commitment on the
            part of the Government and its partners to address potential
            threats to stability and growth are essential. Finally, in
            the context of revising OP 8.50, the Bank should also see
            whether additional guidelines can be developed for the
            specific context and requirements of post-conflict lending operations.

repnme.cdata!:
Republic of Congo - Emergency
            Demobilization and Reintegration Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Emergency Demobilization and
            Reintegration Project aims to a) provide sound post-conflict
            reintegration options to ex-combatants who have joined the
            ranks of the unemployed after the signing of the cease-fire
            agreement; b) help rehabilitate physical and social
            infrastructure; and c) support macroeconomic stability. The
            Bank's involvement will address the immediate
            post-conflict needs of the country; and provide the
            development leadership needed for reengagement of the
            international community in a country in the delicate and
            troubled Central Africa region. Building on ongoing
            Disarmament, Demobilization and Reintegration (DDR)
            activities in the country, this project will also help
            formulate a comprehensive Demobilization and Reintegration
            Program (DDR) in Congo by setting up necessary framework to
            build on donors' support for the DDR program. The
            project will contribute to ongoing efforts to consolidate
            peace and strengthen security in the Republic of Congo,
            while offering sound reintegration options to ex-combatants
            who joined the ranks of the unemployed after the signing of
            the cease-fire agreement. The credit will complement support
            provided by other donors and the Bank's ongoing
            Post-conflict Grant for the Reintegration of Women and Youth.
